title: Overview
body:
We know how busy surgery staff are but we are also aware of the importance of research. This short guide aims to facilitate the implementation of the REST Study at your site. We will take you quickly through the greenlight process so you can be open to recruitment as soon as possible.

The whole process should take no longer than 15 minutes, although obtaining signatures for the delegation log may take slightly longer.

Please Note:

  • CVs should be signed and dated (within 2 years), click the button below to download the template if needed
  • GCP certificates should be dated within 3 years and are only mandatory for the Primary Investigator (PI). If other members of staff have a current GCP certificate this should also be submitted

 

Download the CV template

title: Start
body:
We've put some simplified versions of the documents below.

You'll notice some pins on the documents which indicate the areas that need to be completed on each form. Selecting each pin will provide an info pop up. In that pop up will be a brief explanation of what needs to go there, with an example.

An editable version of each form can be downloaded via the link under the title of each document (or they can be found by clicking the 3 lines in the top right hand corner of the screen).

If you need any assistance please contact your trial centre by emailing person@bristol.ac.uk or calling 0117 9000 000.

title: Site Agreement
body:
Download the Site Agreement Document

Download the Site Agreement

The site agreement is the legal contract between your site and Bristol University. Please take some time to read it before signing it.
instruction: Select the pins to see the areas you need to complete.
mobileInstruction: Use the plus symbol below to see more info and the arrow to cycle through the locations in the document.

_items.title: Site Agreement Page 1
_items.body:
Please fill in the sections highlighted in yellow. 

The date should be written in the format of the following example - 28th August 2019.

Your legally registered address should be written like the example below -

Joe Bloggs Surgery registered at Joe Bloggs Lane, Yorkshire, YO2 PL8

If you have any branch surgeries that will be taking part in the study, then it should be written like the example below -

Joe Bloggs Surgery registered at Joe Bloggs Lane, Yorkshire, YO2 PL8 to include Branch Bloggs, Branch Lane, YO2 PL9

_items.title: Site Agreement Page 9
_items.body: Please could the Practice Manager or Lead GP/PI please sign, print and date page 9.

title: Delegation Log
body:
Download the Delegation Log

The delegation log is in place to provide a comprehensive list of study staff members and the duties that have been delegated to them by the Principal Investigator (PI). The PI should sign off against each staff member to authorise that they agree with the tasks they have been delegated.
instruction: Select the pins to see what info we need.
mobileInstruction: Use the plus symbol below to see more info and the arrow to cycle through the locations in the document.

_items.title: Site PI
_items.body: Please enter the name of your site PI

_items.title: Start Date
_items.body: Start date. This can be today's date.

_items.title: End Date
_items.body: If a member of staff stops working on the study, please put an end date here.

_items.title: Study Tasks
_items.body:
Please list all the study tasks you will be undertaking. 

They should be listed separately, i.e. "A,B,C,D".

Please see the Study Task Codes table on the delegation log if you need any guidance over which tasks apply to you.

_items.title: Signature of PI
_items.body: The site PI should sign in this column against each member of staff. This is to confirm they agree with the tasks allocated.

_items.title: Date
_items.body: This should be the date the PI is signing off against the names.

_items.title: PI Oversight Required?
_items.body: PI oversight is required for any nurse or other healthcare professional listed on the delegation log who will be undertaking eligibility/consent tasks.

_items.title: Signature of PI Confirming Oversight
_items.body: PI to sign here if oversight of any staff members is required.

_items.title: Date
_items.body: Date that the PI signed to confirm oversight.

title: Thanks for filling in the forms!
displayTitle: Thanks for filling in the forms!
body:
Once all documents are complete please email them to person@bristol.ac.uk

On receipt of the documents the study team will send out the relevant training links to each member of staff, with individual logins and passwords. This training should be completed ASAP. Please note that we cannot apply for sponsorship without the PI completing their training.

If you have any queries please ring on 0117 9000 000.
instruction: You've finished! Go back to the menu or feel free to close this page.

title: Background and Study Aims
body:
Middle ear infections, medical term Acute Otitis Media or AOM, are common painful infections in children. Germs multiply in the confined middle ear resulting in a build-up of pressure that stretches the ear drum. In around 1 in 7 children, the ear drum bursts, releasing a liquid (medical term: discharge or otorrhoea) that can be seen coming out of the ear. It is commonly believed that the pain of AOM improves when the ear drum bursts, but research shows that the pain is similar with or without the ear drum bursting.

At the moment nearly all UK children with AOM and discharge (AOMd) seen by their GP/nurse are treated with antibiotics by mouth. These can cause side effects like rashes, diarrhoea and vomiting and more rarely, severe allergic reactions. They can also make the germs in a child’s body resistant to antibiotics. It may be possible to use alternative treatments for ear discharge. One possibility is to use antibiotic eardrops. Research has shown these are better than antibiotics by mouth for children with runny ears and grommets, probably because the antibiotics are given directly to the place they are most needed.

Another potential treatment is a ‘delayed’ antibiotic prescription (where parents are advised to wait to see if the child’s infection improves without antibiotics). Studies in other infections suggest this can be just as effective and safe, but with fewer side effects. Since AOMd is painful and distressing for children and their families it is important to show that any new treatments work at least as well as the current standard treatment (immediate antibiotics by mouth).

The aim of this study is to test whether giving an antibiotic ear drop or a delayed antibiotic by mouth is as good as immediately giving antibiotics by mouth for children (without grommets) who have developed AOMd.

title: What does the study involve?
body: Participants are randomly allocated to one of three treatments: immediate antibiotic ear drops, delayed oral antibiotics or immediate oral antibiotics (usual care), all for 7 days. AOMd symptoms (pain, fever, being unwell, sleep disturbance, discharge, and episodes of distress) are assessed at the start of the study and after 14 days.

title: What are the possible benefits and risks of participating?
displayTitle: What are the possible benefits and risks of participating?
body:
The NHS has paid for and approved this study because evidence suggests the treatment might work.

Participants will be helping research to improve the future treatment for children with ear discharge.

Risks include possible allergic reactions to the antibiotic drops or antibiotics taken by mouth, but the medicines are routinely prescribed in the UK and are considered safe to use for children.

The advice to gently press on the outer ear flap to help the ear drops flow into the ear hole may cause discomfort to some children. If this happens, it is not necessary to continue using the “pumping” method but to simple keep the child’s head tilted to one side for a few extra minutes, to make sure the drops have reached the ear drum.

The collections of the stool samples may prove to be a sensitive issue, and therefore the stool sample collection is optional.

title: Where is the study run from?
displayTitle: Where is the study run from?

title: Organisation of Information Document (OID)
body:
Download the Organisation of Information Document (OID)

The OID allows the sponsor to make clear what activities will be undertaken locally and the cost type for each activity. It's also where you can provide your bank details so we can pay you your research costs.
instruction: Select the pins to see the areas you need to complete.
mobileInstruction: Use the plus symbol below to see more info and the arrow to cycle through the locations in the document.

_items.title: Page 3, Section 9
_items.body: Please fill in the table with your Name, Post, etc.

_items.title: Page 17
_items.body: Please fill in the areas highlighted in yellow.

title: Complete list of documents/information required
body:
• Signed and dated (within 2 years) CVs for all staff taking part (i.e all staff who will appear on the delegation log). Could you please include your work email address on your C.V (even if this means writing it on).
  • PI GCP certificate (dated within 3 years). If any other members of staff have a GCP certificate then please submit these, but it is not mandatory for them to have one.
  • Organisation of Information Document
  • Signed Site Agreement 
  • Delegation Log
